newsitem.title: USA: Highest prices paid at Christie's for animation art since 1989.
newsitem.headline: Highest prices paid at Christie's for animation art since 1989.

text.p: The following is a list of the 10 highest prices paid at Christie's East auctions of animation art since 1989. All the movies were produced by Walt Disney Studios.
DATE PRICE DESCRIPTION
5/16/78 $286,000 "Orphan's Benefit", 1934. Cel set-up of an
orphan mouse punching Donald Duck.
5/16/89 $181,500 "Orphan's Benefit", 1934. Cel set-up of two
orphans.
6/19/90 $104,500 "Lady and the Tramp", 1955. Cel set-up of
Lady and the Tramp, who dine on
spaghetti.6/9/95 $101,500 "The Plough Boy", 1929.
Complete storyboard
drawing of Mickey and Minnie Mouse.
11/28/90 $82,500 "Alice in Wonderland", 1951. Cel set-up of
Alice and the Caterpillar in the gardens.
6/20/91 $88,000 "Cinderella", 1950. Cel set-up of
Cinderella dancing in the moonlight.
6/20/96 $85,000 "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, 1937. Key
set-up of Snow White and three dwarfs,
exactly as the scene appears in the
movie.6/20/91 $79,200 "Alice in Wonderland", 1951.
Cel set-up of Alice in the garden.
5/16/89 $62,200 "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs", 1937.
Cel set-up of Snow White and the Prince.
6/20/96 $57,500 "Lady and the Tramp", 1955. Lady and the
Tramp, "Belle Notte" scene.
Note: A key set-up consists of cels of different characters
laid over a watercolor background, exactly as the scene
appears in the movie.
A cel set-up is similar except that the picture is not
exactly as it appears in the movie.
A storyboard drawing is a draft of the final picture. Source: Christie's
